required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Transdiagnostic Internet-delivered REBT Intervention for Adolescents' Internalizing Problems
clinical_study.official_title: The Efficacy and Mechanisms of Change of a Transdiagnostic Internet-delivered REBT Intervention for Adolescents With Internalizing Problems: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: To investigate the efficacy and mechanisms of change of an Internet-delivered transdiagnostic REBT intervention for adolescents with internalizing problems.

detailed_description.textblock: The main objectives of this study are to evaluate the efficacy and mechanisms of change of an Internet-delivered Rational Emotive Behavior Therapy for adolescents (12-15 years) diagnosed with a principal anxiety or depressive disorder according to DSM-5 criteria. Participants will be randomly allocated to one of the two groups: experimental (REBTonAd) and waitlist control. The intervention is structured in 8 modules and will be delivered over six weeks. Assessments will be conducted at four time points: baseline, post-treatment, 3-month follow-up, and 6-month follow-up.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Internalizing problems measured with the Youth Self-Report 11/18 (YSR; Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks), 6-month follow-up
primary_outcome.description: Change in self-reported internalizing problems from baseline to post-treatment, at 6 months post treatment. Higher scores indicate higher levels of internalizing problems.

secondary_outcome.measure: Automatic Thoughts QuestionnaireShort Version (ATQ-SV; Netemeyer et al., 2002)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks), 6-month follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Change in negative automatic thoughts from baseline. Higher scores indicating higher levels of negative automatic thoughts.

secondary_outcome.measure: The child and adolescent scale of irrationality (CASI; Bernard & Cronan, 1999)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks), 6-month follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Change in irrational beliefs from baseline. Higher scores indicate higher levels of irrational beliefs.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Questionnaire for Measuring Health-Related Quality of Life in Children and Adolescents, The Revised Version - adolescent version (Kiddo-KINDL; Ravens-Sieberer, & Bullinger, 1998)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks), 6-month follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Change in quality of life from baseline from baseline. Higher scores indicate higher levels of quality of life.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Adolescent Peer Relations Instrument (APRI; Parada, 2000)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks), 6-month follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Change in bullying victimization from baseline. Higher scores indicate higher levels of peer victimization.

secondary_outcome.measure: Principal diagnosis based on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5) criteria
secondary_outcome.description: Diagnostic interview for anxiety disorders and/or depressive disorders

other_outcome.measure: The anxiety subscale from The Beck Youth Inventories™ -Second Edition for Children and Adolescents (Beck, Beck, & Jolly, 2005).
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks), 6-month follow-up
other_outcome.description: Change in anxiety subscale from baseline. This subscale contains 20 items, rated on a 4 point Likert scale, with 0 = Never and 3 = Always. The total score is obtained by summing the 20 items, with higher scores indicating higher symptoms of anxiety.

other_outcome.measure: The depression subscale from the Beck Youth Inventories™ -Second Edition for Children and Adolescents (Beck et al., 2005)
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks), 6-month follow-up
other_outcome.description: Change in depression subscale from baseline. This subscale contains 20 items, rated on a 4 point Likert scale, with 0 = Never and 3 = Always. The total score is obtained by summing the 20 items, with higher scores indicating higher symptoms of depression.

other_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after the intervention (an expected average of 6 weeks)
other_outcome.description: Satisfaction with the program. Higher scores indicate higher treatment satisfaction

arm_group.description: Protocol is based on Rational Emotive Therapy (Ellis, 1962, 1994), structured in 8 modules delivered over 6 weeks (Module 1- Introduction and psychoeducation about emotions, Module 2 - Psychoeducation anxiety and depression, Module 3 - Relaxation, Module 4 - Negative patterns of thinking and cognitive restructuring, Module 5 - Problem solving, Module 6 - Exposure and Behavioral activation, Module 7 - Positive emotions and Module 8 - Gaining maintenance)

Participants in the control group will complete pre-treatment and post-treatment assessments. After participants in the experimental group complete post-treatment assessment, they will receive the intervention.

intervention.description: The protocol is based on Rational Emotive and Behavioral Therapy (REBT; Ellis, 1962, 1994). The program will consist of 8 modules, delivered online over six weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age between 12 and 15 years
- A principal diagnosis of Social Anxiety Disorder, Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Panic Disorder, Persistent Depressive Disorder, or Major Depressive Disorder as defined by DSM-5 (APA, 2013)
- Not currently following another treatment (psychotherapy, pharmacological treatment);
- Internet access
- Ability to read and write Romanian
Exclusion Criteria:
- Suicidal ideation
- Severe depression
- Any physical and mental health acute problem that requires hospitalization
- Diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder, psychosis, bipolar disorder or mental disability
